items.title: Syrian government, Kurdish forces agree ceasefire after rapid advance

featured_image.name: Syria live: Government, SDF agree on immediate ceasefire – State media

items.description:
The Syrian government and the U.S.-backed Syrian Democratic Forces reached a ceasefire agreement on Sunday following days of intense combat that saw government troops rapidly advance through Kurdish-held territories in the country's north and east, seizing strategic oil fields and key cities.

Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa and SDF commander Mazloum Abdi signed the 14-point accord, which state media described as an "immediate and comprehensive" halt to hostilities across all fronts. The agreement marks a watershed moment in Damascus's efforts to reassert control over nearly all of Syria following the toppling of Bashar Assad in December 2024.[1][2][3]

items.title: At least 21 dead after two high-speed trains derailed in Spain
items.description: At least 21 people have died and 25 others are severely injured after two high-speed trains derailed in southern Spain, local authorities say.

items.title: Starmer tells Trump tariffs on NATO allies over Greenland are wrong

featured_image.name: Sir Keir Starmer has responded after Donald Trump set out how he plans to  impose tariffs on eight European countries - including the UK - over  Greenland.

items.description:
UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer directly challenged President Donald Trump on Sunday, telling him in a phone call that imposing tariffs on NATO allies over Greenland is "wrong." The conversation came one day after Trump announced sweeping tariffs against eight European nations in his latest effort to pressure Denmark into selling the Arctic territory.

According to an official Downing Street statement, Starmer spoke with Trump after first coordinating with Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, and NATO Secretary-General Mark Rutte. "He said that security in the High North is a priority for all NATO allies in order to protect Euro-Atlantic interests," Downing Street said. "He also said that applying tariffs on allies for pursuing the collective security of NATO allies is wrong."[1]

items.title: Rain event helped create 'perfect storm' for shark attack, authorities say
items.description: Police say the boy was pulled aboard a vessel by water police officers "within minutes" of the Triple Zero call being made.

items.title: EU weighs $108 billion in retaliatory tariffs after Trump targets Greenland

featured_image.name: Europeans reeling as Trump threatens tariffs on 8 countries over Greenland dispute

items.description:
European capitals are considering imposing up to 93 billion euros ($108 billion) in retaliatory tariffs or market restrictions on American companies in response to President Donald Trump's threat to levy escalating duties on eight European nations until the United States is allowed to purchase Greenland, according to the Financial Times.[1][2][3]

The retaliatory measures are being drawn up to give European leaders leverage in pivotal meetings with Trump at the World Economic Forum in Davos this week, the FT reported Sunday, citing officials involved in preparations for the Switzerland meetings.[4][1]

items.title: Iran president warns attack on Khamenei means 'all-out war'

featured_image.name: Iran president warns of 'irreversible' consequences of wider ...

items.description:
Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian declared Sunday that any attack on Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei would be "tantamount to all-out war against the Iranian nation," escalating a war of words with Washington after President Donald Trump called for "new leadership" in Tehran.

"Any aggression against the supreme leader of our country is tantamount to all-out war against the Iranian nation," Pezeshkian wrote on the social media platform X. The Iranian president also blamed Washington for his country's economic struggles, citing "longstanding enmity and inhumane sanctions" imposed by the United States and its allies.[1][2]

Pezeshkian's warning followed a sharp exchange between Trump and Khamenei on Saturday. In an interview with Politico, Trump said "it's time to look for new leadership in Iran," calling the 86-year-old supreme leader "a sick man who should run his country properly and stop killing people". Trump added that Iran under Khamenei's rule was "the worst place to live anywhere in the world because of poor leadership".[3]

items.title: China blocks Nvidia H200 chip imports, halting supplier production

featured_image.name: China's customs agents told Nvidia's H200 chips are not ... - Reuters

items.description:
Chinese customs authorities have blocked shipments of NVIDIA Corporation's H200 artificial intelligence processors, prompting suppliers of specialized components to halt production amid what industry analysts describe as a sudden and unexpected reversal in trade relations between the world's two largest economies.

The move, first reported by the Financial Times on January 16, came after customs officials in Shenzhen summoned logistics companies on January 7 and instructed them not to accept customs clearance applications for H200 chips. Early shipments of H200s were already arriving in Hong Kong when the blockade took effect, catching Nvidia off guard, according to sources familiar with the matter.[1][2][3]

items.title: Iran confirms 5,000 dead in crackdown as protests subside

featured_image.name: Pro-Government Rally Held In Iran As Regime Rejects Threats Of Western Intervention

items.description:
An Iranian official acknowledged on Sunday that authorities have verified at least 5,000 deaths during three weeks of nationwide protests, the first such confirmation from within the government as the Islamic Republic's deadliest crackdown in decades appears to have temporarily suppressed street demonstrations.

The figure, which includes approximately 500 security personnel, was disclosed by a regional official speaking to Reuters on condition of anonymity. The official blamed "terrorists and armed rioters" for the casualties, while attributing support for protesters to "Israel and armed groups abroad." The acknowledgment follows Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei's admission on Saturday that "several thousand" had died during the unrest.[1][2][3][4][5]

items.title: Trump asks Australia, Albanese to join Gaza 'Board of Peace'
items.description: The US president is pushing for the board to preserve a fragile ceasefire between Hamas and Israel and progress the peace deal to the next phase.

items.title: UN report: Global power demand to surge by 2035 as AI strains grids

featured_image.name: Trump DOE gives Microsoft partner $1B loan to restart Three Mile ...

items.description:
The artificial intelligence revolution is reshaping the global energy landscape, with tech giants racing to secure nuclear power contracts as data center electricity consumption threatens to strain power grids worldwide.

Global electricity demand is expected to increase by more than 10,000 terawatt-hours by 2035, a figure equivalent to the total consumption of all advanced economies today, according to a UN report released this week. The International Energy Agency estimates that data center electricity demand grew by more than 75 percent between 2023 and 2024, and the sector is expected to account for over 20 percent of electricity-demand growth in advanced economies by 2030.[1][2][3]

items.title: EU calls emergency meeting after Trump tariff threat over Greenland

featured_image.name: EU warns of downward spiral after Trump threatens tariffs ... - Reuters

items.description:
Ambassadors from the European Union's 27 member states will convene for an emergency meeting on Sunday after U.S. President Donald Trump announced a wave of escalating tariffs on European allies over their opposition to the American acquisition of Greenland, an unprecedented move that threatens to fracture the transatlantic alliance and ignite a new trade war.

Cyprus, which holds the EU's six-month rotating presidency, called the urgent session late Saturday, with diplomats indicating it is scheduled to begin at 5 p.m. GMT. European Council President António Costa confirmed he is coordinating a collective response from member states, stating, "The EU will maintain its stance on upholding international law, wherever it is applicable".[1][2][3]

items.title: EU lawmakers move to freeze US trade deal after Trump tariffs

featured_image.name: EU Set to Halt US Trade Deal Over Trump's New Tariff Threat ...

items.description:
European Union lawmakers are poised to freeze approval of the EU-US trade deal after President Donald Trump announced tariffs on eight NATO allies Saturday in his latest bid to acquire Greenland. The move marks a dramatic escalation in transatlantic tensions, jeopardizing the landmark agreement struck just six months ago.

Manfred Weber, president of the European People's Party—the largest political faction in the European Parliament—declared that proceeding with the trade deal is no longer feasible. "The EPP is in favor of the EU-US trade deal, but given Donald Trump's threats regarding Greenland, approval is not possible at this stage," Weber posted on social media Saturday, adding that "zero tariffs on US products must now be put on hold."[1][2][3]

items.title: Trump asks countries to pay $1 billion for permanent peace board seats

featured_image.name: Trump asks Egypt, Turkey leaders to join Gaza Board of Peace

items.description:
The Trump administration is asking countries that want a permanent spot on President Donald Trump's new Board of Peace to contribute at least $1 billion, according to a draft charter of the body sent to world leaders this weekend.[1][2]

The provision, outlined in the charter distributed alongside invitation letters on Friday, effectively creates a two-tier membership structure. Countries that contribute $1 billion or more in cash funds to the Board of Peace would be exempt from the standard three-year membership term, securing them a permanent seat on the panel.[2]
